metadata.title: Spina Bifida
anatomical location body part affected: Neural tube, majority of the time affecting the lumbar and sacral components of the spinal cord, nerve roots, and vertebrae; spina bifida (SB) can ultimately affect the entire body due to secondary impairments
description: During embryonic development, the neural groove gradually deepens as the neural folds become elevated. The folds ultimately meet and coalesce in the midline, converting the neural groove into a closed tube known as the neural tube or neural canal. The neural tube is the embryo’s precursor to the developing central nervous system (CNS), including the brain and spinal cord. In SB, there is incomplete closure of the vertebral arches surrounding the neural tube, exposing the developing spinal cord and nerves(42)

SB is a type of neural tube defect (NTD), also known as spinal dysraphism. NTDs are a group of serious birth defects that affect the developing nervous system and include SB, anencephaly, and encephalocele(6)

SB literally means “spine split into two” and is technically correct in describing any patient with an incomplete closure of the spinal column. The term SB is sometimes used nonspecifically in the literature with regard to all patients with NTDs. Epidemiologic studies of spinal dysraphism typically include both myelomeningocele (MMC) and meningocele (MC) collectively as SB. There is such a large degree of variation of anatomic malformations associated with such a condition and, therefore, more specific terminology is used(6)
In the United States, the incidence of SB is 3.4 per 10,000 live births(42)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified. In the U.S., patients may qualify for individual state-funded  therapy programs (birth-21)  through contracted therapy vendors and/or the school system. The qualifications are state specific
presentation signs and symptoms: There are three main classifications of SB

SB occulta –Sometimes called “hidden spina bifida”and the mildest form of SB(2) –Typically spinal nerves are normal(2) –There is no opening in the patient’s back(2) –Small defects can be seen in vertebrae visible upon x-ray(2) –There is no protrusion of spinal cord through vertebrae(42) –Individuals may develop mild neurologic decline, observed through slight sensory and/or motor impairment, later on during youth or even as an adult(2) –An atypical collection of fat, a dimple, birthmark, or tuft of hair may be present on patient’s back(3) –May be diagnosed at any time during life; often missed at birth(2) –Usually discovered on an x-ray  later in life when evaluating for a separate medical condition(3)

SB MC –Is a rare form of SB(3) and refers to a protrusion of the meninges and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) through a defect in the posterior elements of the spine into the tissue beneath the skin, without involvement of the functional neural elements(24) –Typically no peripheral nerve or spinal cord damage(2) –Patient may present with mild physical disabilities(2) –Exacerbation of symptoms may occur as individual ages(2)

SBMMC –Most severe type of SB; when individuals refer to SB they are usually speaking about this type(2) –Spinal defect is present in conjunction with a cyst, comprised of meninges and cerebrospinal fluid, which protrudes through the defect in the posterior elements of the spine with involvement of the spinal cord or nerve roots(24) –Risk of serious infections at birth due to nervous tissue exposure(3) –Nerve damage is present(2) –Severe disabilities including paralysis, incontinence, and seizures(3) –Neurological impact above the site of the lesion is attributed to Arnold Chiari malformation and hydrocephalus. Impairments may be motor, cognitive, and perceptual in nature(4) –A subgroup of MMC is known as hemimeningomyelocele(6) -Rare condition in which MMC and a split cord malformation (SCM) are seen -SCM – a “spinal cord duplication” -SCM type I – “Two hemicords, each contained within its own dural sheath, separated by a rigid osseocartilaginous median septum” -SCM type II – “Two hemicords are housed in a single dural sheath with a nonrigid fibrous median septum” -Just one hemicord is present in the MMC -Estimated 2–3%  of patients with SB have this type  -One lower extremity’s function is intact while the other extremity is significantly compromised -Typically the patient is continent in the bladder -Severe scoliosis is present at birth leading to lateral trunk deviation, pelvic obliquity, elevated pelvis, and significant leg length discrepancy -In split cord malformations tethering of the spinal cord can occur and will be indicated by an increase in symptoms –It is highly recommended that if MMC is identified, surgical management be performed in the perinatal period in order to prevent lethal complications from MMC(48)

The terms SB aperta and SB cystica can also be used to refer to both SB MC and SB MMC(24) –SB cystica refers to a sac filled with cerebrospinal fluid protruding from the spinal column(24) –SB aperta refers to a midline defect that communicates with the external environment(24)

Signs/symptoms of complications associated with SB vary greatly depending on the classification, level of the spinal defect, and severity of the condition –Intellectual and cognitive disability(42) –Hydrocephalus(24) -Approximately 15% of those with MMC are born with severe hydrocephalus and require immediate shunting -Presence of hydrocephalus correlates strongly with the level of the spinal defect. Thoracic lesions have a higher incidence than lumbar or cervical -Ventricular enlargement can occur prior to measurable change in head circumference -Delayed-onset  hydrocephalus can present with signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (vomiting, headaches, irritability, somnolence) –Seizures(24) –Chiari malformation (also known as Arnold-Chiari malformation)(24) -Chiari II malformation is characterized by variable displacement of cerebellar tissue into the spinal canal, accompanied by caudal dislocation of the lower brainstem and fourth ventricle -Signs and symptoms -Intermittent obstructive or central apnea -Cyanosis -Bradycardia -Dysphagia -Nystagmus -Stridor -V ocal cord paralysis -Torticollis -Opisthotonos -Hypotonia -Upper extremity weakness -Spasticity -The combination of stridor, central apnea, and aspiration is also referred to as central ventilator dysfunction -Symptomatic Chiari II malformation is the leading cause of death for infants with MMC and operative mortality is relatively high (34% to 38%)(24) –Other congenital anomalies associated with SB: congenital tumors, dermal sinus tract, neuroenteric cysts, diastematomyelia(46) -Hydromyelia: is the dilation of the center canal of the spinal cord and analogous to dilation of the ventricles in the brain(24) -It is very common in children with MMC. It is probably more common than reported because it is often asymptomatic. Symptoms may include: -increase in degree of scoliosis -spasticity -decreased strength or coordination of the upper or lower extremities  –Tethered cord syndrome -Spinal cord can be fixed or “tethered” at one point, causing traction injury to the spinal cord. This can lead to progressive loss of urologic, neurologic, and musculoskeletal function. Tethered cord can develop as a result of adhesions and fibrosis between the intraspinal neural structures, the meninges, and the surrounding vertebral structures following MMC repair. Tethered cord often occurs at lower lumbar or sacral levels. Typical signs and symptoms are(24) -increased weakness -pain -worsening gait -scoliosis -new or worsening of musculoskeletal impairments -urologic dysfunction/sphincter disturbances -trophic ulcers –Neurogenic bladder, often associated with recurrent urinary tract infections due to incomplete emptying of the bladder(24) -Urologic impairment is not correlated with the level of the lesion as in a traumatic spinal cord injury -More than 90% of infants with MMC will have a neurogenic bladder (partial or complete denervation of the bladder), associated with poor compliance and contractibility resulting in abnormal residual urine volume -Urethral sphincter is incompetent in 86% of individuals resulting in incontinence -Approximately one-third  of individuals with SB have detrusor-sphincter  dyssynergia, resulting in high intraluminal pressures -The external sphincter is typically partially functional -Aggressive urinary management during infancy can make a significant impact on the child’s renal health and the ability to develop urinary continence -Hydronephrosis is found in 7% to 30% of infants and reflux occurs in ~20% of infants(24) –Neurogenic bowel -Incontinence due to impaired rectal sensation, decreased internal anal sphincter tone (for those with lesion of L3 or greater), sphincter dysfunction, and altered colonic motility(24) -The presence of cutaneous or bulbocavernosus reflex has been associated with a greater likelihood of achieving bowel continence(24) -Severe chronic constipation(46) –Musculoskeletal complications(24) -Only one-third  of individuals present with flaccid paralysis below the level of the lesion. Most have a combination of upper and lower motor neuron signs(24) -Many present with asymmetric motor and sensory impairments(24) -Decreased bone mineral density with potential for pathological fractures(17) -The hip joint is most often affected due to muscle imbalances at the hip accounting for most of the hip flexion deformity in addition to hip flexor spasticity and prolonged sitting in a wheelchair(24) -Hip subluxation develops due to muscle imbalances -Hip dislocation can occur congenitally or be acquired -Joint contractures at the hips, knees, or ankles(24) -Foot deformities are the most common and present in almost all children with SB -Foot deformities can be present from birth due to lack of intrauterine movement or muscle imbalance. They may also develop over time due to muscle imbalances and weight bearing forces -The most common foot deformities in children with SB are equinus, equinovarus, calcaneus cavus, and rocker bottom deformity(24) -Spinal deformities are more likely to occur in those with thoracic lesions (> 90% of patients with thoracic lesions develop scoliosis)(24) -Impaired gross motor skills and functional mobility, often requiring the need for assistive and adaptive devices –Psychological and social issues(24) -Typically have lower IQ scores compared with typically developing peers  -Verbal IQ is generally greater than their performance IQ on the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC) -Often have more difficulty with math and visual perceptual skills -Children with thoracic lesions tend to have lower IQ scores than children with lumbar and sacral lesions -Tend to have better verbal skills than written skills -They are often described as having verbose but irrelevant conversations, often speaking off-topic and use many routine social phrases –Lumbosacral cutaneous abnormalities, such as a tuft of hair, nevus, lipoma, abnormal blood vessels, dimple, or dermal sinus tract, may suggest the presence of SB but are not definitive signs of SB(46) -In a retrospective study of 54 children in France referred for congenital midline lumbosacral cutaneous lesions, 14 children were diagnosed with spinal dysraphism. Three children presented with one congenital midline lesion and 11 presented with two or more lesions(7) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: SB occulta – The vertebral arch or arches do not fuse; the meninges and spinal cord are not negatively impacted.(5) Morecommon in males and younger patients(50)
SB cystica – The vertebral arch or arches, as well as the neural tube, do not close properly; the meninges alone or themeninges and the spinal cord project through the opening in the spine(5)
Lack of fusion (closure) is thought to be brought about by environmental (e.g., folic acid deficiency) and geneticelements(3)
pathogenesis: In the course of the first 4 weeks of pregnancy, the embryo’s spine should fully close. In the case of a patient with SB, thisclosure does not occur in its entirety, leaving the spinal cord at risk for injury(8)
When the spinal cord and meninges are pushed through a defect in the spine, permanent nerve damage typically results(8)
risk factors: MMC, the most severe form of SB, occurs in ~ 1 in 1,500 births in the United States(9)–In Brazil, the incidence of NTDs was 4.73 per 1,000 deliveries based on 18,807 deliveries in one Brazilian hospital duringthe period 1990–2000.  The incidence was 23.7 per 1,000 stillbirths and 4.16 per 1,000 live births(10)-Distribution: 47% diagnosed with MMC, 27% with anencephaly, 17% with encephalocele, 5.6% with meningocele, and3.4% combination(10)–The incidence of NTDs was 6.57–8.21  per 1,000 deliveries in rural village clusters in India(43)
Prenatal exposure to some antiseizure medications (e.g., valproic acid)(1,2)

Prenatal exposure to antimalarial drugs during the first trimester may be associated with SB(11)–Based on a case series, researchers reported 41 consecutive cases of SB seen over 44 months in one teaching hospital inNigeria in which all 41 mothers had ingested antimalarial drugs during the first trimester of pregnancy(11)

Maternal obesity(1,2)–Based on a meta-analysis  of 12 studies, the risk of NTDs increased with increasing degree of obesity with an odds ratio of3.11 for NTDs in newborns of severely obese women(12)–Higher maternal weight at 15–20  weeks’ gestation was associated with a higher risk of open NTDs in a retrospectivecohort of 420,362 women in Ontario, Canada. Two hundred ninety-two  cases had open NTDs(12)

History of a prior delivery of offspring with an NTD increases risk(1,13)–Based on a retrospective study of 271 mothers interviewed at a mean of 18 years after birth of a child with an NTD (SB oracephaly), there was a 4% overall recurrence rate. Previously, the reported recurrence rates were 3.0%–3.2%  in the UnitedStates and 2.2% in Alberta, Canada(13)
Higher body temperatures early on in pregnancy(2,3)

Exposure to chronic low-dose  radiation is associated with increased risk of NTDs(14)–Based on a retrospective cohort study of 96,438 births in Rivne Province (area of Ukraine exposed to 1986 Chernobylnuclear power plant explosion) and in Polissa region (ongoing chronic low dose of radiation exposure due to highlycontaminated soil and food) compared to Europe during the period 2000–2006–NTDs per 10,000 births: 22.2 overall vs. 9.43–15.34  in Europe based on European surveillance reports for the same years–Twenty-seven  in Polissa vs. 18.3 in outside-Polissa regions
NTDs are seen more frequently in Hispanic women than in non-Hispanic women and in White women more frequently thanBlack women(1,2)
Greater number of female babies born with SB(1,2,3)

Vitamin B12 or maternal folic acid deficiency(3)–Based on mid-level  evidence, retrospective analysis of three nested case-control  studies with baseline differences,researchers concluded that lower vitamin B12 levels during pregnancy may be associated with an increased risk ofNTDs(15)-Two hundred seventy-eight  pregnant women with a current or prior NTD-affected  pregnancy and 901 matched pregnantwomen in the control group had their blood levels of vitamin B12 measured at a median gestational age of 15 weeks-Mothers with fetuses that developed NTD had 13–19% lower vitamin B12 levels mothers with fetuses that did notdevelop an NTD. They also received little or no folic acid supplementation–In the United States, the incidence of SB decreased from 1995 to 2002 based on an analysis of 11,078 births from 21states. This was during the period of transition to mandatory folic acid fortification(16)-Incidence of SB (per 10,000 births) decreased from 1995–1996  to 1998–2002  from 6.49 to 4.18 in Hispanic patients,from 5.13 to 3.37 in non-Hispanic Caucasian patients, and from 3.57 to 2.9 in non-Hispanic  African Americanpatients(16)-The incidence (per 10,000 births) further decreased in non-Hispanic  African American patients from 2.17 pre-2000to 1.74 in 2003–2005.  During this period, the incidence remained nearly constant for non-Hispanic  Caucasians andHispanics(16)

overall contraindications precautions: There is a very high risk of latex sensitivity in individuals with SB(18) The incidence of latex allergy in the general population is estimated to be less than 2%; however, the prevalence among children with MMC ranges from 20% to 65%(24) An individual’s response can vary from mild (e.g., watery eyes) to life-threatening  (anaphylaxis) symptoms It is widely recommended to avoid all products constructed with latex in this population Examples of products/strategies: Latex-free  wheel-chair  seat cushions, gloves can be worn when propelling w/c to avoid latex exposure from tire, and the use of weighted toys instead of Theraband

Shunt malfunction (observe for some of the potential signs and symptoms listed below) Swelling along the site of the shunt(5) Irritability(5) Bulging fontanels (soft spot) in infant(5) Headaches(2) Nausea(2) V omiting(2) Seizures(2) Change in intellect, performance, or personality(2)
The child’s hips should not be ranged beyond neutral (adduction) as hip dislocations are common in this population(5)
Please also see Complications of SB , above
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -What is the nature of current reason for evaluation? -What type of SB does the child/adult have? When was the individual diagnosed? -What is the lesion level? The level of neurologic impairment guides healthcare professionals’ expectations for functional outcome, as well as future musculoskeletal deformities(24) -Does the patient have a shunt? If so, any complications? -Is the patient followed by physicians other than a neurologist and general practitioner?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management The infant will undergo surgical closure of the defect and to prevent infection soon after birth. Early closure (within 72neural plaque is returned to the canal, and the dura and arachnoid are reconstructed; a myofascial closure over the newly constructed neural tube is performed; and the skin is finally closed(24) Hydrocephalus often develops following repair of the open defect and some medical centers advocate simultaneously performing a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt procedure(24) Some physicians have begun to repair the impacted site on the fetus during pregnancy(5) It is estimated that more than 400 fetuses worldwide have undergone in utero closure of MMC by open maternal-fetal surgery(24) Results from a U.S. randomized trial indicate that prenatal surgery for MMC can reduce the need for shunt replacement compared to postnatal repair(19) One hundred eighty-three  women whose fetuses had MMC were randomized to prenatal surgery before 26 weeks’ gestation vs. standard postnatal repair Trial terminated early before recruitment of 200 planned patients after preplanned interim analysis demonstrated efficacy of prenatal surgery At the 12-month  follow-up,  158 women had participated in the survey. Results indicated better outcomes in all areas (necessity for shunt placement, respiratory distress development, hindbrain herniation, mortality rate) for those babies that underwent prenatal surgery vs. postnatal repair A shunt may be placed for the management of hydrocephalus due to associated Arnold-Chiari malformation(24) Surgical correction should be considered as early as possible to repair tethered cord syndrome to have the best possible outcomes. Delayed correction can result in irreversible loss of function(24) Data collected from 2,172 patients from ten specialized SB clinics participating in the U.S. National Spina Bifida Patient Registry (NSBPR) study indicate that a ventricular shunt was the most common surgery (65.7%)(45)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  SB can be diagnosed during a woman’s second trimester of pregnancy.(42) Blood tests,
ultrasound, and/or amniocentesis may be utilized.(3) Xray  (performed for other reasons later in life) may identify vertebral defects indicative of SB occulta
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help any of the patient’s symptoms or not
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any noted aggravating or easing factors
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms. An estimated 3050%  of individuals with SB who have paraplegia experience shoulder pain. This is crucial as significant pain can lead to lost function(20)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -A U.S. study assessing pain frequency, duration, location, and intensity in children with SB found(21) -fifty-six  percent of children had pain at least 1x/week -ambulation abilities and level of lesion were not associated with certain types or locations of pain -younger children’s pain was considerably underrated by their parents -the majority of children with pain were not being treated for their discomfort
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician. Does the child have bowel and bladder control? Is the child catheterized for bladder function?(45)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any respiratory compromise present? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history Has the patient undergone any surgical procedures? Shunt placement? Shunt revisions? Recent hospital admissions? Infections?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Does the patient work or attend school?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -What is the patient’s primary mode of mobility within the home and community? -Does the child attend school? If so, what grade? What is the child’s primary mode of mobility at school and within the classroom? -What is the patient’s level of assistance for ADLs? -How does the patient manage bowel and bladder function? Independence with toileting in children is delayed more than all other self-care  tasks, regardless of intelligence. Most children achieve independent control of bowel and bladder function by 4 years of age, although some might not achieve this goal until 10 to 15 years of age due to the level of paralysis, intelligence, impaired visuospatial skills, kyphoscoliosis, parental support, sensation, sphincter control, and bladder perception. Children can be taught to perform clean intermittent catheterization as early as 5 years of age(24) -Does the family feel they have necessary support in place to assist with the patient? -Is the older patient living independently? Does the patient work? If so, describe the job duties. How does the patient access the community (drive, public transportation, car rides)?
social and occupational history.living environment: Number of floors within the home and number of stairs to enter the home? With whom does patient live (e.g., siblings, caregivers)? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Complete a home assessment as indicated

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting):
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Assess for a leg length discrepancy. If present, is it functional or a true leg length discrepancy? Document patient’s height, weight, and body mass index (BMI) and compare to age and gender normative data
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –What equipment is currently used? –Is equipment appropriate in fit? Is it in need of repair? –Has the child’s growth necessitated height adjustments on equipment?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Assess static and dynamic balance reactions, protective extension, and righting reactions in sitting and standing –The Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS), the balance section of the Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2), or the Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2)  can be used –If available, use a Balance System to quantify a patient’s balance impairments -Researchers in Sweden conducted a controlled study involving 15 children with MMC (and 20 typically developing peers) to determine if seated postural sway differences could be measured using a force plate. The study found significant differences during frequency analysis of the horizontal ground reaction force between the two groups. The authors concluded that this method of objective measurement can detect variations from normal that cannot be picked up on by visual observation alone(22)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Document vital signs and include the Dyspnea Scale or Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale for fatigue level. Consider using the Wheelchair Perceived Exertion Scale (WHEEL SCALE) as an alternative to the Borg RPE Scale. The WHEEL SCALE was developed to assess RPE for individuals with impaired lower extremities with mild cognitive or perceptual impairments(41)
Note distance patient is able to ambulate or propel w/c prior to fatigue. The 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) can be used
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Circulation –Assess bilateral radial and pedal pulses –Authors of a small controlled Dutch study of individuals with SB and acquired spinal cord injuries (SCIs) reported that vascular properties, including decreased blood flow, small diameter, and high shear stress, were present in SB and SCI groups (more significant differences were noted in the SB group when compared to the control subjects). This study demonstrated that individuals with SB may have abnormalities in their vascular system and these differences may be even greater than what is observed in individuals with acquired SCI(23) Coordination –Researchers in Sweden conducted a controlled study to assess individuals’ ability to program and execute reaching movements. Results of the study indicate that precision and coordination during the task of reaching are the most challenging elements of reaching for these individuals to control(4) –Use the BOT-2  bilateral coordination subscale for children aged 4 to 14 years Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity –Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity myotomes and note any asymmetries Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.) –Assess basic functional mobility such as sit to stand, stand pivot transfers, stair negotiation, and bed mobility. If patient is not independent, assess caregivers independence with assisted functional mobility skills and note any ergonomic concerns
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Complete a gait evaluation as indicated. Note the use of assistive devices. Note any gait abnormalities or asymmetries –It is important to note that hip flexion contracture ≥ 20° will impede gait(24) Joint integrity and mobility –Assess bilateral upper and lower extremities for joint mobility, noting any asymmetry or abnormality  –Joint contractures can develop at the hips, knees, or ankles. Hip flexor contractures are most common. At the knee, flexion or extension contractures can develop(24) -A patient may still be able to ambulate with ≤ 20° knee flexion contracturescongenital or acquired. Acquired hip dislocations can occur as a result of unopposed hip flexor and adductor muscle strength or tone –The posterior glenohumeral joint capsule is often found to be shortened in patients who primarily utilize w/c’s(20) –The most common foot deformities in children with SB are equinus, equinovarus, calcaneus cavus, and rocker bottom deformity(24) –Assess for any joint contractures; hip flexor contractures are common(24) Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) and neuromotor development –Assess child’s ability to move through the developmental sequence as able and appropriate(5)(5) -Alberta Infant Motor Scale (AIMS); can be implemented up to 18 months -PDMS-2;  can be used from birth to age 6 years to assess development -Bayley Scales of Infant Development, Third Edition is a comprehensive assessment tool and can be used up to 42 months of age -BOT-2;  standardized for ages 4–14  years
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Manual muscle test (MMT) for bilateral upper and lower extremities and trunk should be formally tested and charted as indicated. MMT can determine the level of the lesion based on specific charts(5) –In small children, strength can be assessed through mobility or spontaneous movement(6) –The strength of certain key muscles has a tremendous impact on the potential for independent ambulation. Those muscles include iliopsoas, gluteus medius, gluteus maximus, quadriceps, medial hamstring, and anterior tibialis(13)
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess tone throughout trunk and extremities

Note the presence of any skin ulcers or pressure sores. If present, note location, size, color, and odor. Patients with SB are at an increased risk for poor wound healing and the development of pressure ulcers secondary to decreased circulation and lack of sensation(23) •Perception  (e.g., visual field, spatial relations)

Standardized tests should be implemented as indicated and appropriate to assess perception; examples include(8) -Beery-Buktenica  Developmental Test of Visual-Motor Integration (Beery-VMI) -Motor-Free  Visual Perception Test-3  (MVPT-3) -Test of Visual Perceptual Skills, Non-Motor,  Revised (TVPS-[n-m]-R)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Assess posture in sitting and standing as indicated, with and without braces –Eighty-five  percent of children with MMC will develop foot deformities(24) –Hip flexion contractures can cause anterior pelvic tilt causing increased lumbar lordosis(24) –Common spinal postures include scoliosis, kyphosis, and excessive lordosis. Scoliosis is a typical comorbidity with thoracic lesions(24) –Fifty percent of children with MMC will experience a subluxed or dislocated hip.(24) Test for developmental hip dysplasia with the Galeazzi sign, Ortolani or Barlow maneuvers
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess active and passive ROM for upper and lower extremities –Individuals who utilize w/c’s as their primary method of locomotion typically develop tightness in the pectoralis, biceps, and trapezius muscle groups(20) –Hip dislocation is often associated with a hip adduction contractures(24) –Approximately 70% of children will develop a knee flexion contracture by age 8 (with a lesion of L3 or above)(24)
relevant tests and measures.self-care activities of daily living: Self-care/activities  of daily living –In a Dutch study measuring functional independence in young adults with SB, results indicated that the majority of patients without hydrocephalus were independent in all categories on the FIM assessment tool with the exclusion of sphincter control. For 165 individuals with SB and hydrocephalus, assistance requirements were correlated to the level of the lesion. The higher the lesion (L2 or above) the greater the requirement for assistance according to the FIM(25) –Based on retrospective review of 24 South Korean children with MMC who underwent intravesical electrical stimulation (a medical intervention where a transurethral electro-catheter  is inserted into the bladder) for neurogenic bladder, researchers concluded there was a significant improvement in bowel and bladder continence(26) –Researchers in the U.S. conducted a cross-sectional  study of individuals with SB and concluded that bowel and bladder incontinence was associated with SB aperta, hydrocephalus, and a lesion level of L5 or above. Furthermore, the majority of subjects in the study reported increased social-emotional feelings of having bowel and bladder incontinence(27)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Reflex testing –Assess bilateral deep tendon reflexes for ankle, knee, and elbow  –Assess for the presence of primitive reflexes such as Babinski, asymmetric tonic neck reflex(5)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity dermatomes, as well as sharp-dull  and light touch(5)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Is the child alert and oriented X 4? Does the patient make good eye contact? –Can the child/adult follow commands? How many steps? Is the patient able to focus and attend to task? Does the patient need frequent redirection to complete a task? –Use the Neonatal Behavioral Assessment Scale for newborns(5)

other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what the patient’s physician orders. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Physical therapy is critical for a child born with SB. The facets of intervention are many and include the prevention of deformity, maximizing strength and functional independent mobility, and patient and caregiver education. Treatment intervention will vary depending on the patient’s age and level of lesion. Treatment intervention is often long term, but with periods of no intervention depending on the patient’s functional levels, surgical intervention, and/or new injuries that may arise
prognosis: Almost all children with SB are able to achieve some degree of independent mobility. Ambulation can become highly inefficient and time-consuming;  however, it is a goal that is desired to be achieved. Many teenagers and young adults will choose wheelchair mobility when given the opportunity due to high energy cost that ambulation demands. The ability for a child to become ambulatory and maintain ambulatory function is multifactorial. It is determined by the level of the lesion, cognitive ability, motivation, musculoskeletal complications, growth, age, and BMI(24) –Most patients with lumbar lesions will achieve some level of ambulation but lose this skill as they enter growth spurts and adolescence(24)

Based on a retrospective cohort study of 5,165 infants with SB born between 1979 and 2003 in the United States, there has been an overall improved survival rate –From 88% to 96% in Whites, 79% to 88% in Blacks, and 88% to 93% in Hispanics(28)

Two main determinants of outcome in a patient with SB are the level of the lesion and if the patient has hydrocephalus(25,28) –The higher the level of the lesion, the more impairments and functional limitations an individual will have(9,25) –Based on a U.S. retrospective study of 36 children diagnosed with SB at a mean age of 27 weeks’ gestation and then assessed at a mean age of 3.2 years(29) -An increasing degree of cerebellar herniation on MRI was found to be associated with an increased risk of childhood seizures, high-risk  bladder dysfunction, and inability to ambulate independently(29)

Infants who have perineal sensation may have a better prognosis than patients without it in cases of open SB(30) –Based on a U.K. prospective cohort study of 117 patients with open SB whose backs were closed nonselectively at birth between 1963 and 1971  –Twenty-eight  percent of the individuals had perineal sensation (within 2 days of birth) defined as “intact sensation to pinprick in at least one dermatome on one side in the saddle area (S2-4)” –Results when comparing infants with perineal sensation vs. without -70% vs. 32% of individuals survived -0 vs. 23% died from renal causes -43% vs. 4% of survivors had bladder continence -78% vs. 33% of survivors had bowel continence -48% vs. 19% survivors were able to walk a minimum of 50 meters

Sensation present over a greater proportion of the body at birth is associated with improved mobility and reduced need for daily care in adulthood in patients with open SB(31) –Based on a prospective cohort study in the U.K. of 117 consecutive patients with open SB and surgical repair within 48 hours of birth who were then followed for up to 43 years. Sixty-one  percent of those who participated had a sensory level of L3 at birth and 17% had a sensory level of T1 at birth –Researchers reported at a mean of 40 years follow-up -Sensation beginning at a higher level was associated with an increased ability to walk and reduced the need for daily care. Comparing sensory level L3 vs. T1: 61% were able to walk vs. 0% and the need for daily care was 22% vs. 71% -No significant associations between sensation level and ability to live independently, to drive a car, or to be employed -Those individuals who did not have a shunt or those with a shunt but without a revision were associated with an increased ability to walk, live independently, drive a car, and not require daily care compared to those who underwent shunt revisions

Swedish researchers conducted a study to determine the effects of MMC on health-related  quality of life (HRQOL)(38) –Child Health Questionnaire-50,  Parent Form (CHQ-PF50)  was completed by the parents of 62 children, as well as a physical examination of the lower extremities and review of medical history –Nonambulatory children with MMC had significantly more frequent spasticity in the lower extremities, joint contractures, hip dislocation, or spinal deformities compared to ambulatory children with MMC –Thirty-two  percent of the ambulators managed without wheelchair use –All nonambulators were wheelchair users, of which 60% used both a manual and a powered wheelchair –Children with SB reported lower HRQol on all subscales of the CHQ-PF50  compared with a control group of children without medical issues –Physical function was significantly higher in ambulatory children with MMC compared with nonambulatory children with MMC

Due to medical advances in the management of SB, the number of adults living with SB has increased dramatically over the past decades. Seventy-five  percent to 85% of individuals with SB survive into early adulthood.(24) Young adults with SB have a multitude of health issues requiring collaborative care within their healthcare team(40) –Results from a 2010 systematic review suggest that adults with SB report health concerns stemming from the long-term effects of hydrocephalus, neuromuscular weakness, neurogenic bowel and bladder, and musculoskeletal disorders(39) –Young adults with SB report difficulties with full community participation, as evidenced by poor rates of employment and independent living and by limited peer relationships(40) –Several studies have observed significant differences in QOL scores between young adults with SB and their typically developing peers(40) –Individuals who develop chronic pain are at even greater risk of reporting significantly lower QOL scores(40) –Up to 10% of adults with VP shunts develop chronic idiopathic headaches(24)

Maternal fetal MMC surgery is associated with improved functional outcomes in infants with SB MMC(49) –Authors collected information from 42 patients who underwent fetal MMC surgery –At 10-years  follow-up,  79% (n = 33) of the patients were community ambulators, 9% (n = 3) were household ambulators, and 14% (n = 6) were wheelchair dependent –Only 26% had normal bladder function –Children who underwent fetal MMC surgery had deficits in executive function in three Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF) indices compared with population norms
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines –Capsulotomy or soft tissue release may be necessary in a patient with high lesion level who presents with chronic seating malalignments(24) –Patients older than age 10 with a low level lesion may present with deteriorating ambulation and require a subtrochanteric extension osteotomy(24) –A radical hip release may be indicated in patients with hip flexion, abduction, and external rotation contractures(24) –*Note: efficacy was not reported on the above described procedures Authors of a small prospective study of 12 Italian patients with SB found that a lower disability score (increased independence) was associated with increased psychological suffering; the patients who were independent with mobility but had urologic dysfunction required more psychological support than patients with more severe disabilities(32) Refer to occupational or speech therapy as indicated Referral to pain management team(24) Referral to social work, counselor, or psychiatry as indicated for patient and/or caregivers –U.S. researchers conducted a study to assess HRQOL in 159 individuals aged 5 to 20 years with SB (125 with MMC, 25 with lipomyelomeningocele, and 9 with other dysraphisms). Patients with MMC had significantly lower overall HRQOL scores than patients with closed spinal dysraphism. Younger patients with MMC had overall higher HRQOL scores. Those with impaired bowel continence had lower overall HRQOL(47)
treatment summary: Therapeutic exercises –In a U.S. noncomparative study of six children (three had MMC) who underwent circuit training for 8 weeks to improve w/c propulsion, statistically significant improvements were found in muscle strength testing and the 12-minute  distance testing. There was not a significant improvement seen in the 50 meter test(33) –Authors of a U.S. controlled clinical trial assessing an 8-week  upper body exercise program in patients with SCI and SB who had shoulder pain found the intervention reduced pain and improved satisfaction and function in these individuals(20) -Forty-one  subjects who were primary manual wheelchair users participated in the study -Subjects in the intervention group were instructed in a home exercise program consisting of stretching and strengthening exercises for the shoulder girdle -Subjects in the control group who reported no pain and did not present with shoulder impingement symptoms received no intervention -Strengthening was focused on the serratus anterior, middle and lower trapezius, and rotator cuff -Stretching was primarily to the upper trapezius, pectoralis muscles, and posterior capsule -Subjects in the intervention group had significant improvement in reported pain (Wheelchair User’s Shoulder Pain Index) and function (Shoulder Rating Questionnaire) following the 8-week  program. There was no change in the control group –An intensive progressive resistance exercise (PRE) program can improve gait, endurance, and lower extremity strength individuals with SB(51) -Based on an 8-week  case study of a 14-year-old adolescent with MMC -Intervention consisted of exercises that targeted the “power-  generating” and stabilizing muscles of the lower extremity, as well as a cardiopulmonary endurance training program

Functional training –U.S. researchers conducted a controlled study to assess body-weight-supported  treadmill stepping in infants with SB compared with a control group of 12 infants with typical development(34) -Infants were tested on the treadmill at age 1, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months with no treadmill training between test sessions. Infants were supported on the treadmill for twelve 20-second  trials with digital camera analysis -Results indicated that as time passed (first year of life) infants with SB were observed taking less steps than the control group. Responsiveness was affected by the lesion level but varied markedly among infants. Infants responded greater to a moving treadmill than a nonmoving treadmill -The authors concluded that early body-weight-supported  treadmill stepping has the potential to foster ambulation earlier in infants’ development and assist in counteracting the motor delay that appears to be present from very early on  –Authors of a study conducted in the U.S. have found positive benefits to the use of an in-home  body weight support system in order to improve functional mobility and ambulation in a child with SB(52) -Based on a 10-week  study of a 5-year-old  boy with SB. The child used the device for 2.7 days/ week for up to 67 minutes/ day while participating in self-selected activities

Orthoses –General recommended criteria for implementation of reciprocating gait orthosis (RGO) in the literature(35) -Lumbar level lesion -Access to treatment center -Parental collaboration -Symmetric motor function and upper extremity strength -Lean body mass -Absence of mental retardation -Mild lower extremity contractures -Mild scoliosis –In a study of 70 Israeli children with MMC at level L3 or above(35) -Seventy percent of children were successful and prescribed their own RGO -Neurological level and parental cooperation were significant factors in predicting success with a RGO -Researchers recommended “pre-prescription”  trial to avoid financial waste as many kids are not successful with RGOs even though they meet the general recommended and vastly accepted criteria. Children who may not meet the generally accepted inclusion criteria are provided a trial with the device (as indicated and appropriate) to allow for potential success -The duration of ambulation with the RGO was positively correlated to ease of access to a treatment center

Alternative interventions –Authors of a U.S. case series explored the impact w/c dancing had on children with MMC. Four subjective social-emotional findings were noted(36) -“Unconditional Acceptance” – described as a “bond,” “sense of belonging,” and “acceptance” from other children who could relate to them -“A dream come true” – reportedly the children experienced their bodies in a “joy filled and skillful manner” -“Beyond the W/C” – the w/c was used in a creative manner and the children described a feeling of freedom -“A stronger self” – children found themselves in positions of leadership and developed new skills . maintenance or prevention: Folic acid supplementation recommendations The American Academy of Pediatrics supports U.S. Public Health Service, American College of Medical Genetics, and American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommendations: –All women planning or capable of becoming pregnant ingest 400mcg of folic acid/day to prevent NTDs. This may be in the form of a multivitamin, fortified foods, or a combination. This is particularly important prior to conception and during the first trimester(1) –Women who have previously had a NTD-affected  pregnancy, who were themselves diagnosed with an NTD, have a first- or second-degree  relative with an NTD, or who have diabetes mellitus, type 1 (DM1) may be advised to take 4mg starting 3 months prior to conception, if planning to conceive and continuing throughout the first trimester. Genetic counseling is advised to determine their occurrence or recurrence risks, pregnancy management, and the appropriate folic acid intake. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends increasing intake of folic acid to 4mg/day beginning at least 1 month prior to conception and continuing through the first trimester(1) -Based on a Cochrane systematic review of five randomized and quasi-randomized  trials evaluating daily periconceptual folic acid supplements with or without other vitamins and minerals in 6,105 women(44) -Compared to placebo/control, daily periconceptual folic acid supplementation through 12 weeks’ gestation was associated with a significant reduction in overall NTDs and NTDs in women with a previous history of NTD-affected pregnancy(44) The Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists in Canada issued its practice guidelines(1) –Education for all women of reproductive age about the importance of folic acid supplementation –Women of reproductive age should maintain a healthy diet –Consumption of a daily, recommended multivitamin –5mg of folic acid ingested to not only prevent recurrence of NTDs but also cleft lip/palate, heart defects, limb defects, urinary tract abnormalities, and hydrocephalus –5mg of folic acid will not mask vitamin B12 deficiency –Primary prevention could be accomplished with: 1-4 mg/day of folic acid from supplements and/or fortified food or 5mg for high-risk  groups In 1998, the United States, Canada, and several other countries instituted folic acid fortification of foods, with the U.S. policy of fortifying enriched grain products with 140mcg/100g of folic acid as a mandate(1) –This was implemented because nearly half of all pregnancies are unplanned and because folic acid supplementation compliance has been found to be fairly poor in various published studies(1) –As of 2011, Finland did not permit folic acid fortification of food, citing as the reason the need to determine possible risks of fortification(1) -The main risk of increased folic acid is the masking of megaloblastic anemia caused by a vitamin B12 deficiency. This is generally not an issue for women of reproductive age but rather for women > 65 years of age(1) Folic acid fortification is associated with a reduction in incidence of NTDs based on observational studies in Canada(37) –Food fortification with folic acid was mandated in Canada in 1998  –Incidence of NTDs per 1,000 births decreased from 1.58 prior to fortification to 0.86 during full-fortification  period. This was based on a national study of 1,909,741 births from seven Canadian provinces during the period 1993–2002 –American College of Medical Genetics states there is no evidence to support increasing fortification of foods with folic acid greater than the current levels since studies have produced conflicting or inconclusive results about the risks and benefits of increasing fortification of foods(1) Prenatal screening allows for the diagnosis of the majority of cases of MMC before birth(24) –Recommendations for initial screening of pregnant women (maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein  and acetylcholinesterase levels) at 15–20  weeks postconception who are at high risk include maternal age > 35 years or prior if mother has a history of NTD-affected  pregnancy, positive family history, or known exposure to teratogenic agents. Based on these results, a patient-specific  risk can be calculated and repeat testing of serum levels as indicated(24) –Routine second trimester high-resolution  ultrasound has a 95% sensitivity rate. However, if the images are of poor quality due to maternal obesity or other factors, amniocentesis can be performed to obtain amniotic fluid alpha-fetoprotein  and acetylcholinesterase levels at 14–18  weeks postconception(24) –Prenatal detection of SB is important to educate the patient and family regarding the diagnosis and management options. Genetic counseling should also be provided. Early detection allows for the medical team to prepare for a safe delivery in a medical center that can perform surgical repair to the neonate(24) It is important for individuals with SB to be transitioned to a multidisciplinary adult healthcare team that is capable of managing adults with SB. Some patients may choose to be followed by their pediatric providers into adulthood if there is not an appropriate adult care team in their vicinity(24) –Adults with SB remain at risk of developing neurologic complications such as VP shunt infections and malfunctions, syringomyelia, and symptomatic type II Chiari malformation –Ideally, adolescents and young adults with SB can be transitioned from a pediatric SB clinic to a multidisciplinary adult spinal cord injury clinic. The long term health care needs of individuals with SB are similar to those with spinal cord injuries, such as bowel and bladder management, personal hygiene, self-management  skills, mobility, vocational planning, and sexual adaptation(46) -U.S. researchers conducted a study to assess the effectiveness of transitioning 24 adolescents and young adults with SB from a pediatric SB clinic to an adult spinal cord injury clinic. Interviews were conducted with 24 subjects and 16 parents. The overwhelming majority of participants (82%) were very pleased with the transition despite having initial concerns regarding the transition. They reported having the unexpected benefit of being “treated like an adult and were the focus of the care”
